p: The scientifically identified, described and measured climate change impacts and vulnerability may differ from household perspectives. Leiserowitz et al. ( 2010) and Dessai, Kandlikar and Risbey ( 2005) stated that lay public perceptionsâ€™ and interpretation of climate change and its hazards are based on psychological, social, moral, institutional and cultural processes. The expert definitions based on probabilities and severity of consequences are narrower than the lay public, which have multidimensional and complex sets of assessments. Public perceptions regarding climate change and hazards of climate change are not only shaped by scientific and technical descriptions of hazards, but by a variety of psychological and social factors that encompass personal experience, effect and emotional, imagery, trust, values and worldviews (Slovic 2012).
